title: Add frontend UI for DKIM configuration in SMTP sending profiles
description: Add form fields in the SMTP sending profile UI to configure DKIM signing (enable/disable toggle, domain, selector, private key input). This will make DKIM configuration accessible to non-technical users.

title: DKIM private keys stored in plaintext - security concern
description:
The DKIM private key is stored in the database as plaintext in the dkim_private_key column. This is a security vulnerability - if the database is compromised, attackers could sign emails as legitimate domains.

Recommendation: Encrypt DKIM private keys at rest using the same pattern as other sensitive configuration.

title: Panic on delete group
description: Upstream issue #1731. GoPhish panics when deleting a group. Need to investigate and fix.

title: Add email deliverability metrics and analytics
description: Track email delivery success rates, spam folder placement, and DKIM verification status per campaign. Provide dashboard to visualize deliverability trends and identify issues.

title: Add IMAP OAuth 2.0 support for Microsoft 365
description: Upstream issue #2026. Microsoft disabled basic auth for IMAP/POP3. Need OAuth 2.0 support for email reporting feature to work with M365 tenants.

title: API key exposed in DOM and reset doesn't invalidate old keys
description: Upstream issue #9366. API key is embedded in page JavaScript on every login. Regenerating key doesn't invalidate old one. Fix: Don't embed API keys in client-side code, use session-bound tokens for UI.

title: Generate and document DKIM key pair generation instructions
Add DKIM signature verification in campaign results
description: Add a field in campaign results to show DKIM signature status. This will help users verify that emails are being properly signed and track deliverability improvements.

title: validateFromAddress regex may reject valid RFC 5321 email addresses
description:
The validateFromAddress function in models/smtp.go uses a regex pattern that may be too restrictive:
^([a-zA-Z0-9_\-\.]+)@([a-zA-Z0-9_\-\.]+)\.([a-zA-Z]{2,18})$

This pattern:
- Only allows alphanumeric, underscore, hyphen, and dot characters
- Doesn't support subdomains with more complex structures
- May reject valid RFC 5321 addresses with special characters

Consider using the mail.ParseAddress() result directly instead of adding the regex validation.

title: Session logout does not invalidate server-side session cookie
description: Upstream issue #9368. Logging out doesn't invalidate the session on the server - cookie remains valid allowing persistent account takeover. Fix: Invalidate and destroy server-side session on logout.
